Award.AwardTitle: A Novel Post-transcriptional Regulatory Mechanism Mediated by Zhx2

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: It has become increasingly clear that transcriptional and post-transcriptional steps of gene expression are coupled, interdependent and potentially co-regulated. Much of the evidence for regulating mRNA processing through coupling with transcription is derived from artificial systems. While these models demonstrate the capacity for regulating post-transcriptional steps of gene expression through interactions with transcriptional machinery, there are few natural examples of where this occurs in vivo. Recently, the Zinc fingers and homeoboxes 2 (Zhx2) gene was cloned and shown to be responsible, in part, for repressing the expression of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) and other genes in the liver after birth. Published studies have shown that the AFP promoter is sufficient to confer Zhx2 regulation on a heterologous reporter gene. However, preliminary results have shown that the transcription rate across the AFP gene is the same in the presence or absence of Zhx2, even though AFP mRNA accumulation is repressed. Moreover, this repression occurs because splicing of multiple AFP introns is inhibited. Because Zhx2 functions in a promoter-dependent manner but acts at a post-transcriptional level, this system provides a unique opportunity to understand a biologically relevant and novel mechanism that couples transcriptional to post-transcriptional gene regulation. Based on preliminary studies, it is hypothesized that Zhx2 acts through the promoter of its target genes to decrease the splicing efficiency of the nascent RNA and thus reduce fully processed mRNA levels. To test this hypothesis and investigate mechanistic details, mice that express a FLAG-tagged Zhx2 transgene, but low levels of endogenous Zhx2, have been generated. Using these mice, this project will determine whether Zhx2 is a direct or indirect regulator of AFP expression and whether it associates with target promoters or along the whole gene by using chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) assays. Combining ChIP with DNA sequencing will identify other Zhx2-regulated genes. The mechanism of AFP RNA splicing repression will be investigated by comparing the pol II complex in the presence or absence of Zhx2 by ChIP. Whether splicing repression occurs co-transcriptionally will be determined by measuring splicing of nascent RNA. Finally, this project will identify proteins that interact with Zhx2, which will provide essential information about Zhx2 function. The components of FLAG-Zhx2-containing protein complexes from adult mouse liver will be identified by mass spectrophotometry. The long-term goal of the project is to understand Zhx2-mediated regulation of AFP because it is a novel regulatory mechanism that appears to couple transcription to post-transcriptional events in the liver. Details of this mechanism will lead to a better understanding of gene regulation at the step of RNA biogenesis.

Broader impacts: Graduate, undergraduate, and, potentially, high school students will be involved in the research, building on the laboratory's strong history of student training. Results of the research will be shared with the broader scientific community through national meeting presentations and publications. Scientifically, the research has the potential to uncover novel insights into a poorly understood mechanism of gene regulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We have been studying the mouse alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) gene as a model system to understand mechanisms of gene regulation. This gene is highly expressed in the fetal liver, but then is repressed within four weeks after birth and only reactivated when the liver is damaged or diseased. In the early 1980s, one strain of mice, BALB/cJ, was shown to have incomplete repression of AFP in the adult. About ten years ago, we identified Zhx2 as the gene that is mutated in BALB/cJ mice and responsible for this phenotype. Little is known about how Zhx2 or the other members of this small gene family, Zhx1 and Zhx3, regulate gene expression although there were suggestions that they may be transcriptional repressors. However, our data in mice showed that the AFP gene was transcribed at the same rate in two mouse strains that differed in their levels of AFP expression due to the presence or absence of Zhx2. This suggested that Zhx2 may regulate gene expression at a post-transcriptional level. Identifying this regulatory mechanism was the goal of this project. Specific outcomes include:

1. We discovered and characterized novel antisense non-coding RNAs that overlap with about the last half of the AFP gene. We identified several alternatively spliced antisense AFP (asAFP) RNAs that were all about 5 kb long. We used standard and quantitative RT-PCR techniques, as well as mouse liver RNA-seq data, to characterize these RNAs.

2. The abundance of the asAFP RNA is inverse to that of AFP mRNA, during development and between mouse strains with or without Zhx2.

3. asAFP RNAs accumulate in the cytoplasmic poly(A)+ RNA fraction.

4. The asAFP promoter is located about 7 kb downstream from the AFP gene. We identified core promoter elements and tested whether Zhx2 may regulate the asAFP promoter. However, co-expression of Zhx2 in cell lines did not affect expression of the asAFP promoter.

5. We expressed segments of the asAFP RNA in a mouse liver cell line and found that they could decrease AFP mRNA levels. By modifying the segments expressed, we find the portions of asAFP that overlap with AFP mRNA exons are more effective than segments that overlap with AFP introns. This suggests asAFP affects the AFP mRNA abundance after the pre-mRNA is synthesized and spliced, possibly by affecting nuclear-cytoplasmic transport or cytoplasmic mRNA stability.

6. While we have found the asAFP RNA levels and Zhx2 expression inversely correlate with AFP mRNA levels, we still have not found a direct connection between Zhx2 and AFP regulation. This correlation could be due to an indirect effect. We have identified Zhx2 binding sites genome-wide by chromatin-immunoprecipitation-sequencing and are in the process of analyzing and confirming the data. We do not detect direct Zhx2 binding in or around the AFP gene, suggesting this is an indirect target of Zhx2. finding and characterizing direct targets of Zhx2 are goals for future work.

7. We have also examined other genes that are disregulated in mouse liver with a normal or deleted Zhx2 gene with partial support from this grant. We published that Zhx2 positively regulates Mouse Urinary Protein (Mup) genes, which is opposite to AFP’s regulatory pattern. We also published that several liver-expressed cytochrome p450 (Cyp) genes are differentially expressed in mice with normal or deleted Zhx2 genes. Further, the sex of the animal determined whether several of the Cyp genes responded to Zhx2 status.

Broader Impacts. In addition to the discovery of a novel antisense ncRNA, this project provided training opportunities for a number of female students. An undergraduate student, a master’s student and two PhD students all contributed to this project. One of these PhD students, who is from a group that is underrepresented in the STEM fields, completed her thesis research working on this project. Multiple posters describing this work were presented at national and local meetings. Data for two papers have been generated.
